poem_title: THE DESCRIPTION OF A Salamander. Out of Pliny Nat. Hist. L. 10. C. 67 and L. 29 C. 4.
author: Jonathan Swift
poem_alt_title: Out of Pliny Nat. Hist. L. 10. C. 67 and L. 29 C. 4.

lines.line_text: As Mastive Dogs in Modern Phrase are
Call'd  and
As  and  are often stil'd
With Christian Nick-names like a Child;
As we say,  to an
Without offence to Human Shape:
So men have got from Bird and Brute
Names that would best their Natures suit:
The  and
Were Hero's Titles heretofore,
Bestow'd as Hi'roglyphicks fit
T'express their Valor, Strength or Wit.
For, what is understood by
Beside the getting of a Name?
But e're since Men invented Guns,
A different way their Fancy runs;
To paint a Hero, we enquire
For something that will conquer Fire,
Would you describe  or
Think of a Bucket or a Pump.
Are these too low? — then find out grander,
Call my Lord C— a .
'Tis well. — But since we live among
Detractors with an evil Tongue,
Who may object against the Term,
shall prove what we affirm:
shall prove, and we'll apply,
And I'll be judg'd by standers-by.

stanzas.stanza_text:
As Mastive Dogs in Modern Phrase are
Call'd  and
As  and  are often stil'd
With Christian Nick-names like a Child;
As we say,  to an
Without offence to Human Shape:
So men have got from Bird and Brute
Names that would best their Natures suit:
The  and
Were Hero's Titles heretofore,
Bestow'd as Hi'roglyphicks fit
T'express their Valor, Strength or Wit.
For, what is understood by
Beside the getting of a Name?
But e're since Men invented Guns,
A different way their Fancy runs;
To paint a Hero, we enquire
For something that will conquer Fire,
Would you describe  or
Think of a Bucket or a Pump.
Are these too low? — then find out grander,
Call my Lord C— a .
'Tis well. — But since we live among
Detractors with an evil Tongue,
Who may object against the Term,
shall prove what we affirm:
shall prove, and we'll apply,
And I'll be judg'd by standers-by.

lines.line_text: FIRST then, our Author has defin'd
This Reptil, of the Serpent kind,
With gawdy Coat, and shining Train,
But loathsom Spots his Body stain:
Out from some Hole obscure he flies
When Rains descend, and Tempests rise,
Till the Sun clears the Air; and then
Crawls back neglected to his Den.

stanzas.stanza_text:
FIRST then, our Author has defin'd
This Reptil, of the Serpent kind,
With gawdy Coat, and shining Train,
But loathsom Spots his Body stain:
Out from some Hole obscure he flies
When Rains descend, and Tempests rise,
Till the Sun clears the Air; and then
Crawls back neglected to his Den.

lines.line_text: SO when the War has rais'd a Storm
I've seen a  in human Form,
All stain'd with Infamy and Vice,
Leap from the Dunghill in a trice,
Burnish and make a gaudy show,
Become a General, Peer and Beau,
Till Peace hath made the Sky serene,
Then shrink into it's Hole again.
Salamander!

stanzas.stanza_text:
SO when the War has rais'd a Storm
I've seen a  in human Form,
All stain'd with Infamy and Vice,
Leap from the Dunghill in a trice,
Burnish and make a gaudy show,
Become a General, Peer and Beau,
Till Peace hath made the Sky serene,
Then shrink into it's Hole again.

Salamander!

lines.line_text: FARTHER, we are by  told
This  is extreamly cold,
So cold, that put it in the Fire,
'Twill make the very Flames expire,
Beside, it Spues a filthy Froth,
(Whether thro' Rage or Love, or both)
Of Matter Purulent and white
Which happ'ning on the Skin to light,
And there corrupting to a Wound
Spreads Leprosy and Baldness round.

stanzas.stanza_text:
FARTHER, we are by  told
This  is extreamly cold,
So cold, that put it in the Fire,
'Twill make the very Flames expire,
Beside, it Spues a filthy Froth,
(Whether thro' Rage or Love, or both)
Of Matter Purulent and white
Which happ'ning on the Skin to light,
And there corrupting to a Wound
Spreads Leprosy and Baldness round.

lines.line_text: SO have I seen a batter'd Beau
By Age and Claps grown cold as Snow,
Whose Breath or Touch, where e'er he came,
Blew out Love's Torch or chill'd the Flame:
And should some Nymph who ne'er was cruel,
Like  cheap, or fam'd ,
Receive the Filth which he ejects,
She soon would find, the same Effects,
Her tainted Carcase to pursue,
As from the  Spue;
A dismal shedding of her Locks
And, if no Leprosy, a Pox.
Salamander.

stanzas.stanza_text:
SO have I seen a batter'd Beau
By Age and Claps grown cold as Snow,
Whose Breath or Touch, where e'er he came,
Blew out Love's Torch or chill'd the Flame:
And should some Nymph who ne'er was cruel,
Like  cheap, or fam'd ,
Receive the Filth which he ejects,
She soon would find, the same Effects,
Her tainted Carcase to pursue,
As from the  Spue;
A dismal shedding of her Locks
And, if no Leprosy, a Pox.
,
Salamander.
